Authors: Priananda I., Stevani M., Sutanto T.I., Mariani M.
Title: Grassroots economy towards cashless society: An empirical analysis of micro-merchant’s readiness in continuing the usage of cashless payment system
Source title: International Journal of Scientific and Technology Research
Affiliations: Management Department, BINUS Business School, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Priananda, I., Management Department, BINUS Business School, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Stevani, M., Management Department, BINUS Business School, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Sutanto, T.I., Management Department, BINUS Business School, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Mariani, M., Management Department, BINUS Business School, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Abstract: Mobile payment or cashless payment system is rapidly developing in the last few years. Cashless payment system is an emerging market in Indonesia. There are many of users and merchants that have been adopting cashless payment system replacing the conventional transactions. Micro-merchant is one of the stakeholders of mobile payment ecosystem which specifically receiving the low-value payment transaction from the mobile payment users. To measure micro-merchant’s readiness in continuing their usage on cashless payment system, we used the Technology Readiness Index (TRI) 2.0 approach. Parasuraman and Colby (2014) developed TRI 2.0 as a research scale in measuring and classifying individuals by their propensity to adopt technology. This research will provide the highlights of current situation of micro-merchant’s technology readiness and their continuance intention to adopt cashless payment system based on TR constructs. There are four constructs which are Optimism, Innovativeness, Discomfort and Insecurity that will be tested to find their relationship to the continuance intention in adopting cashless payment system. This research found that optimism is a determinant factor driving the micro-merchants’ continuance intention to adopt cashless payment system while discomfort is becoming main inhibitor. © 2020 IJSTR.
Author Keywords: Cashless payment system; Micro-merchant; Mobile payment; Technology readiness; TRI

Authors: Mariani M., Firmanzah F., Balqiah T.E., Wahyuni S.
Title: The roles of functional competencies, dynamic capability and technology flexibility in crafting product superiority: A study of Indonesian packaged software developers
Source title: Pertanika Journal of Social Sciences and Humanities
Affiliations: Binus Business School, Bina Nusantara University, DKI Jakarta, 12240, Indonesia; Department of Management, Faculty of Economics and Business, Universitas Indonesia, Depok, West Java, 16424, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Mariani, M., Binus Business School, Bina Nusantara University, DKI Jakarta, 12240, Indonesia; Firmanzah, F., Department of Management, Faculty of Economics and Business, Universitas Indonesia, Depok, West Java, 16424, Indonesia; Balqiah, T.E., Department of Management, Faculty of Economics and Business, Universitas Indonesia, Depok, West Java, 16424, Indonesia; Wahyuni, S., Department of Management, Faculty of Economics and Business, Universitas Indonesia, Depok, West Java, 16424, Indonesia
Abstract: Strong software product development competencies, including customer competence, technical competence and managerial competence, have been identified as critical factors in crafting product superiority. However, given the great degree of uncertainty, software developers must continually cope with extremely rapid changes that demand innovative technological and managerial responses. Based on dynamic capability theory and strategic organizational flexibility, this study developed a theoretical model to explore the effect of dynamic capability and technology flexibility on product development competencies and product superiority. Data were collected from 112 business executives from packaged software firms in Indonesia. Partial Least Squares (PLS) analysis supports the study's hypotheses that when dynamic capability and technology flexibility are introduced to the model, the relationship between a software firm's functional competencies and product superiority becomes insignificant. The findings can provide guidelines for software developers to cultivate dynamic capability and pursue technology flexibility to craft superior software products. © Universiti Putra Malaysia Press.
Author Keywords: Dynamic capability; Product development competencies; Product superiority; Technology flexibility

Title: The viability of proximity mobile payment implementation using near field communication (NFC) technology in Indonesia
Source title: Knowledge Management and Innovation: A Business Competitive Edge Perspective - Proceedings of the 15th International Business Information Management Association Conference, IBIMA 2010
Affiliations: Binus University International, Binus Business School, Jakarta, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Mariani, M., Binus University International, Binus Business School, Jakarta, Indonesia; Dihardja, J.W., Binus University International, Binus Business School, Jakarta, Indonesia
Abstract: This study analyzes the viability of implementing proximity mobile payment technology using Near Field Communication (NFC) in Indonesia and to provide guidance on ideal mechanism which considers all related technical and business-related requirements. The study examines various literatures in NFC technology and implementation, including standard bodies' white papers, case studies on pilot projects around the world, patents, recent articles, journals and supplementary books. Comparing to other alternatives of mobile payment, the proximity mobile payment using NFC technology clearly has an advantage. Not only it is fast, secure, and intuitive, the implementation of NFC opens up a new world of opportunities to be used for other value-adding purposes aside from proximity mobile payment services. The benefits and potential growth in Indonesia supports business cause for investing in this breakthrough payment service. Proposed mechanism is also in place.
Author Keywords: Business model; Mobile payment; Near field communications
Index Keywords: Knowledge management; Mobile telecommunication systems; Business modeling; Mobile payment; Near field communications; Nfc technologies; Payment services; Potential growth; Provide guidances; Standard bodies; Global system for mobile communications

Authors: Widjaja N.D., Imam K., Mariani M.
Title: A study of Green IT awareness among IT professionals in Indonesia
Source title: Business Transformation through Innovation and Knowledge Management: An Academic Perspective - Proceedings of the 14th International Business Information Management Association Conference, IBIMA 2010
Authors with affiliations: Widjaja, N.D., Binus International University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Imam, K., Binus International University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Mariani, M., Binus International University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Abstract: The awareness of IT professionals to Green IT is important to be studied in order to measure whether they are ready to implement Green IT or not. Many countries already implemented Green IT initiatives to reduce carbon emissions. Studied about the level of awareness of Green IT has been done in many countries, except Indonesia. Indonesia has committed to reduce carbon emission by 26% in 2020 and Green IT is one of the potential ways to be implemented to achieve the goal. This proposed paper is going to use survey that has been done previously by RMIT University and Info~Tech to get the level of awareness of Green IT among IT professionals in Indonesia. The results then will be compared to other countries and to highlight the opportunities to increase the awareness level in Indonesia. Following study will be under taken to assess the Green IT readiness index of companies in Indonesia as per Green IT framework developed by previous researchers.
Author Keywords: Awareness; Carbon emissions; CO2; Environmental footprint; Green IT; Readiness
Index Keywords: Information management; Awareness; Carbon emissions; CO2; Environmental footprints; Green IT; Readiness; Knowledge management
